message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Perianal fistulas are a common finding in Crohn disease, while the other options are associated with ulcerative colitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Perianal fistula is a common symptom of Crohn disease, while left lower quadrant pain and loss of large bowel haustra are more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis. Mucosal and submucosal ulcerations can be present in both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Perianal fistula is strongly associated with Crohn disease. Left lower quadrant pain, loss of large bowel haustra and mucosal and submucosal ulcerations are also associated with inflammatory bowel disease, but not specifically with Crohn disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While all options could suggest inflammatory bowel disease, the presence of perianal fistula is more commonly associated with Crohn disease. Left lower quadrant pain is more common in ulcerative colitis. Loss of large bowel haustra and mucosal and submucosal ulcerations could be seen in both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation and can occur anywhere from the mouth to the anus. Perianal fistula is a classic symptom of Crohn disease. Left lower quadrant pain and loss of large bowel haustra are more common in ulcerative colitis, while mucosal and submucosal ulcerations can occur in both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Perianal fistulas are more commonly associated with Crohn's disease than ulcerative colitis, making option (D) the correct choice. Left lower quadrant pain and loss of large bowel haustra are more likely with ulcerative colitis, while mucosal and submucosal ulcerations are common to both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.
